facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1966 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the order dated June 7, 8, 1963 of the Government

facts.text: Appeal against order dated June 7, 8, 1963 of Government of India, Ministry of Finance, Department of Revenue in Central Excise Revision Application No. 463 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: from the order dated June 7, 8, 1963 of the Government of India, Ministry of Finance  Department of Revenue  in Central Excise Revision Application No. 463 of 1963.

facts.text: Appellant is a public limited company manufacturing and selling wholesale paper and boards at Brajrajnagar in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a public limited companypany which carries on the business of manufacturing and selling wholesale, paper and boards at Brajrajnagar in the State of Orissa.

facts.text: Appellant holds licence under Central Excise Act in Form L-4 prescribed by Central Excise Rules, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany holds a licence under the Central Excise Act in Form L-4 prescribed by the Central Excise Rules, 1944.

facts.text: Appellant's factory and premises demarcated under Excise Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypanys factory and its premises and precincts have been demarcated under the said Rules.

facts.text: Factory traversed by railway lines due to private siding.

anchor.surface_text: The Factory is traversed by railway lines, because the appellant companypany enjoys the benefit of a private siding.

facts.text: In 1960, appellant constructed new railway siding outside original factory premises where bamboos and raw materials stored and platform for loading/unloading.

anchor.surface_text: In 1960, the appellant Company companystructed a new railway siding outside the original factory premises where bamboos and other raw materials were stored and companystructed a platform for loading and unloading.

facts.text: New siding extension not included in factory or premises for Excise Rules purposes.

anchor.surface_text: This extension has number been included in the factory or its premises or precincts for purposes of the Excise Rules.

facts.text: To reach new siding, public road traversed which is not enclosed and public cannot be excluded.

anchor.surface_text: It is presumably so, because to reach the new siding, a public road has to be traversed which is number enclosed and from which public cannot be excluded.

facts.text: Appellant requested Excise authorities to amend licence to include new siding, but refused.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that after this new siding was companystructed, the appellant companypany requested the Excise authorities to amend the licence to include the new railway siding but this was refused.

facts.text: On February 27, 1961, appellant loaded 20 wagons of paper after clearance by payment of excise duty under r.52.

anchor.surface_text: On February 27, 1961, the appellant companypany loaded 20 wagons of paper after effecting clearance of these goods by payment of the excise duty under r. 52 of the Excise Rules.

facts.text: On February 28, 1961, appellant loaded 13 more wagons and cleared them.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28, 1961, the appellant companypany loaded 13 more wagons and cleared them.

facts.text: Wagons sealed by railway administration and railway receipts issued to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: These wagons were sealed by the railway administration and railway receipts were issued to the appellant companypany.

facts.text: Appellant obtained gate pass.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany also obtained gate pass.

facts.text: Wagons passed into control of railway administration, but shunted into new siding due to no pilot engine.

anchor.surface_text: The wagons then passed into the companytrol of the railway administration, but as pilot engine was number available, the wagons were shunted into the new siding.

facts.text: Exit from new siding only through factory premises as railway track comes to dead-end.

anchor.surface_text: The exit from the new siding is only through the factory premises because the railway track companyes to a dead-end on the other side.

facts.text: Deputy Superintendent of Central Excise wrote on March 1, 1961 that wagons loaded Feb 27 and 28 found inside factory premises till 9-45 A.M. March 1, liable to higher duty from March 1.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Superintendent of Central Excise wrote to the appellant companypany on March 1, 1961 that the wagons loaded on February 27 and 28, 1961 were found inside the factory pre- mises till 9-45 A.M. on March 1, 1961

facts.text: Appellant contended wagons sealed after loading in presence of Deputy Superintendent, taken out of factory premises, not in factory when new rates into force.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant companypany companytended before the Deputy Superintendent that the, wagons were duly sealed after the companypletion of loading in his presence, were taken out of the factory premises and were number in the factory

facts.text: Appellant relied on r.9A, duty payable at rate in force on date duty paid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany relying upon r. 9A of the Central Excise Rules, 1944 submitted that duty was payable at the rate in force on the date on which the duty was actually 1- ,. aid.

facts.text: Alternatively, appellant submitted goods removed from factory before midnight Feb 28, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, the appellant companypany submitted that the goods having been cleared or removed from the factory premises before the midnight of February 28, 1961,

facts.text: Deputy Superintendent demanded Rs. 45,475.83 as differential excise duty, not accepted contentions.

anchor.surface_text: These companytentions were number accepted by the Deputy Superintendent who demanded payment of Rs. 45,475.83, from the appellant companypany as differential excise duty.

facts.text: Amount paid under protest without prejudice to rights of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The amount was paid under protest and without prejudice to the rights of appeal and representation to the proper authorities under the Excise Act.

facts.text: Assistant Collector, Central Excise, Cuttack rejected refund claim, confirmed collection.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then placed by the appellant companypany before the Assistant Collector, Central Excise, Cuttack and the companypany requested that the differential duty be refunded as it had been illegally companylected. The Assistant Collector rejected the claim

facts.text: Appeal to Collector of Central Excise, Calcutta and Orissa dismissed on March 12, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany appealed the Collector of Central Excise, Calcutta and Orissa but the appeal was dismissed on March 12, 1962.

facts.text: Revision application No. 473 of 1963 to Government of India rejected on June 7/18, 1963, no reason given.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant companypany then filed an application for revision against the order of the Collector of Central Excise, Calcutta and Orissa before the Government of India  Central Excise Revision Application No. 473 of 1963 . The application for revision was rejected by the Government of India on June 7/18, 1963.

facts.text: Duty on paper and boards increased by s.13 Finance Act, 1961 (Act XIV of 1961) read with item 17 of Schedule, payable from March 1, 1961 under Provisional Collection of Taxes Act XVI of 1931.

anchor.surface_text: The duty of excise on paper and boards was increased by s 13 of the Finance Act, 1961  Act XIV of 1961  read with item 17 of the Schedule. Under the Provisional Collection of Central Taxes Act  XVI of 1931  this duty became payable from the 1st day of March, 1961.

facts.text: Court finds new siding not part of factory as Excise authorities refused to include it.

anchor.surface_text: Here the difficulty in the way of the Union of India is that the Excise authorities themselves refused to recognise this portion as part of the factory.

facts.text: Goods put in wagons after payment of duty, wagons sealed, shunted out on gate pass, free of enhanced duty.

anchor.surface_text: if the goods were put in the wagons after payment of duty, and the wagons were sealed and shunted out of the factory proper on a gate pass, number only under the ruling of the Board but also on the application of the Rules as explained here these goods became free of the enhanced duty.

facts.text: Recovery of differential duty erroneous, must be refunded.

anchor.surface_text: The recovery was accordingly erroneous. The duty companylected must, therefore, be refunded and we order accordingly.
Appeal by special leave from the order dated June 7, 8, 1963 of the Government of India, Ministry of Finance  Department of Revenue
The duty of excise on paper and boards was increased by s 13 of the Finance Act, 1961  Act XIV of 1961  read with item 17 of the Schedule.

concepts.unlisted_description: Increases duty on paper and boards read with item 17 of Schedule

anchor.surface_text: Under the Provisional Collection of Central Taxes Act  XVI of 1931  this duty became payable from the 1st day of March, 1961.

concepts.unlisted_label: Provisional Collection of Central Taxes Act XVI of 1931
concepts.unlisted_description: Makes increased duty payable from March 1, 1961

anchor.surface_text: 9A.  1  Alteration of duty or tariff valuation.- The rate of duty and the tariff valuation  if any  applicable to goods cleared on payment of duty shall be the rate and valuation  if any  in force on the date on which duty is paid, or if the goods are cleared from a factory or a warehouse, on the date of the actual removal of such goods from such factory or warehouse Provided that if the goods have previously been removed from warehouse under bond to be rewarehoused, and the duty is paid on such goods without their being rewarehoused, the rate and valuation  if any  applicable thereto shall be the rate and valuation  if any  in force on the date on which duty is paid or, if duty is paid through an account-current maintained with the Collector under Rule 9, on the date on which an application in the proper form is delivered to the officer-in-charge of the warehouse from which the goods were removed

concepts.interpretation: First part applies where duty paid before or at clearance (critical time: date duty paid); second part where goods removed without prior duty payment (critical time: actual removal). In this case, duty paid synchronously with clearance via gate pass before new rates, so old rate applies.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ore-rooms or place. The store-room or place must be declared by the manufacturer and approved by the Collector. To this rule there is an exception and

concepts.unlisted_description: Alteration of duty or tariff valuation based on date of payment or removal

anchor.surface_text: Clearance on payment of duty.- When the manufacturer desires to remove goods on payment of duty, either from the place or premises specified under rule 9 or from a store-room or other place of storage approved by the Collector under rule 47, he shall make application in triplicate  unless otherwise by rule or order required  to the proper officer in the proper Form and shall deliver it to the officer at least twelve hours  or such other period as may be elsewhere prescribed or as the Collector may in any particular case require or allow  before it is intended to remove the goods. The officer shall, there- upon, assess the amount of duty due on the goods and on production of evidence that this sum has been paid into the Treasury, or paid to the account of the Collector in the Reserve Bank of India or the State Bank of India, or has been despatched to the Treasury by money- order shall allow the goods to be cleared.

concepts.interpretation: Provides procedure for clearance of manufactured goods on payment of duty; payment precedes or accompanies issuance of gate pass for removal.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ore-room or other place of storage approved by the Collector under rule 47, he shall make application in triplicate  unless otherwise by rule or order

concepts.unlisted_description: Clearance of manufactured goods on payment of duty

anchor.surface_text: Time and manner of payment of duty.-   1  No excisable goods shall be removed from any place where they are produced, cured or manufactured or any premises appurtenant thereto, which may be specified by the Collector in this behalf, whether for consumption, export, or manufacture of any other commodity in or outside such place, until the excise duty leviable thereon has been paid at such place and in such manner as is prescribed in these Rules or as the Collector may require, and except on presentation of an application in the proper form and on obtaining the permission of the proper officer on the form Provided that such goods may be deposited without payment of duty in a store-room or other place of storage approved by the Collector under rule 27 or rule 47 or in a warehouse appointed or licensed under rule 140 or may be exported under bond as provided in rule 13 Provided further that such goods may be removed on part payment of duty leviable thereon if the Central Government, by notification in the Official Gazette, allow the goods to be so removed under rule 49 Provided also that the Collector may, if he thinks fit instead of requiring payment of duty in respect of each separate consignment of goods removed from place or premises specified in this behalf, or from storeroom or warehouse duly approved, appointed or licensed by him keep with any person dealing in such goods an account-current of the duties payable thereon and such account shall be settled at intervals not exceeding one month, and the account-holder shall periodically make deposit therein sufficient in the opinion of the Collector to cover the duty due on the goods intended to be removed from the place of production, During manufacture or storage.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits removal of excisable goods until duty paid, with exceptions for storage, warehousing, bond export, part payment, account-current; premises specified by Collector.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: y order in writing from time to time approve and appoint a public warehouse and may in like manner license private warehouses for the storage of excis

concepts.unlisted_description: Time and manner of payment of duty; no removal without payment except specified cases

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act lays down inter alia that there shall be levied and collected in such a manner as may be prescribed duties of excise on all excisable goods which are produced or manufactured in India at the rates setforth in the First Schedule.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3, Central Excise and Salt Act 1944
concepts.unlisted_description: Levy and collection of excise duty on excisable goods produced/manufactured in India

anchor.surface_text: Section 4, which is headed Determination of value for the purposes of duty, provides that where any article is chargeable with duty at rates dependent on the value of such article such value shall be deemed to be the whole sale cash price for which an article of like kind and quality is sold or is capable of being sold at the time of the removal of the article chargeable with duty from the factory or any other premises of manufacture or production for delivery, etc.

concepts.interpretation: Value determined at time of removal from factory.

anchor.surface_text: The Act further defines factory to mean any premises including the precincts wherein excisable goods are manufactured, or wherein or in any part of which any manufacturing process connected with the production of these goods is being carried on or is ordinarily carried on

concepts.interpretation: New siding not part of factory as not demarcated/included by Excise authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Excise Act defines excisable goods to mean goods specified in its First Schedule and subject to a duty of excise.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 52A which provides for the actual removal of the goods from the factory. The rule provides that no excisable goods shall be delivered from a factory except under a gate pass signed by the owner of the factory and counter signed by the proper officer.

concepts.interpretation: Gate pass required for removal, presented before actual removal.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 51A then provides that except as otherwise expressly provided for in the Rules, no duty-paid goods shall be allowed to re-enter or be retained in, any part or premises of factory.

concepts.interpretation: Duty-paid goods cannot re-enter factory premises.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: fore it is intended to remove the goods. The officer shall, there- up

concepts.unlisted_description: No re-entry or retention of duty-paid goods in factory

anchor.surface_text: Rule 47 is headed Goods may be stored without payment of duty. Under this rule a manufacturer has to provide a storeroom or other place of storage at his premises for depositing goods made on the same premises without payment of duty.

concepts.unlisted_description: Storage without payment of duty in approved store-room

anchor.surface_text: Rule 140 deals among other matters with the appointment and licensing of warehouse. Under this rule the Collector shall by order in writing from time to time approve and appoint a public warehouse and may in like manner license private warehouses

Rule 7 provides that every person who produces, cures or manufactures any excisable goods or who stores such goods in a warehouse shall pay the duty or duties leviable on such goods at such time and place and to such person as may be designated in or under the authority of the Rules

concepts.unlisted_description: Payment of duty on excisable goods at designated time/place

issues.text: whether the goods are to bear the old duty or the new

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, arises whether the goods are to bear the old duty or the new. This question depends upon the time at which the duty was payable on the goods in this case.

issues.text: depends upon the true construction of r. 9A of the Central Excise Rules, 1944

anchor.surface_text: This question depends upon the time at which the duty was payable on the goods in this case. That in its turn depends upon the true construction of r. 9A of the Central Excise Rules, 1944.

arguments.claim: First part of r.9A is main rule for payment time (unmanufactured goods Ch IV), second part exception for removal time (manufactured goods Ch V)

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the learned Solicitor General on behalf of the Union of India submits that the main rule is in the first part and the second part of the rule is an exception. He suggests that one part speaks of payment of duty and the other of removal

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot be read based on classification of chapters IV and V; rules apply to both types of goods

holdings.text: The rate of duty applicable to goods cleared on payment of duty is the rate in force on the date duty is paid if payment precedes or is synchronous with removal; otherwise, the date of actual removal from factory or warehouse.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's chapter-based distinction; Rule 9A applies to both manufactured/unmanufactured goods; two parts distinguish payment timing relative to removal.

holdings.text: In this case, payment of duty was synchronous with clearance as gate pass issued only after payment, so first part of Rule 9A applies and old rate governs.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the payment of duty was synchronous with the clearance of the goods because the gate pass can only be issued when the goods have actually been cleared for removal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Rule 9A and Rules 52/52A requiring payment evidence before gate pass issuance.

holdings.text: Construction of Rules aligns with Board of Revenue's 1957 ruling that sealed wagons after loading and railway receipts issuance are not factory stock.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Board's interpretation consistent with court's reading of payment/clearance rules.

holdings.text: New railway siding outside original demarcated premises and refused inclusion by Excise authorities is not part of factory or precincts.

anchor.surface_text: Here the difficulty in the way of the Union of India is that the Excise authorities themselves refused to recognise this portion as part of the factory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factory defined by demarcated premises specified under Rules; authorities' refusal binding.

holdings.text: Goods loaded into sealed wagons after duty payment, gate pass obtained, and shunted to new siding are cleared from factory and free of enhanced duty.

anchor.surface_text: if the goods were put in the wagons after payment of duty, and the wagons were sealed and shunted out of the factory proper on a gate pass, not only under the ruling of the Board but also on the application of the Rules as explained here these goods became free of the enhanced duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines Rule 9A first part, gate pass under Rule 52A, non-factory status of siding, and Board precedent.

holdings.text: Demand and recovery of differential duty erroneous; collected duty must be refunded.

anchor.surface_text: The recovery was accordingly erroneous. The duty collected must, therefore, be refunded and we order accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower authorities erred in applying enhanced rate post-clearance under old rate.
